text:
I love this recipe! I have made some changes that make it easier for me on a weeknight: I put the chicken (sometimes I even use frozen-solid breasts or thighs) in a crockpot with the taco seasoning, garlic powder, onion powder, chili powder, chopped onion + a little water in the morning.  Then when I get home from work the chicken is easily shredded and I add the other filling ingredients to the crock pot and stir it up. Then I just assemble per the directions.  I also use green sauce instead of red. This way it only takes 15min to get them in the oven and the meat tastes great from simmering all day in the spices.  Thanks Angela!

text:
This was very good, as is. But with a few minor changes, you can make this in  a LOT less time (and less dishes!). As another reviewer mentioned, I placed the frozen chicken breasts in a crock pot on low with chili powder, onion, taco seasoning, garlic powder and onion powder. That evening I shredded the chicken inside the crock pot in under 2 minutes, added the green chilies, and lime juice. In a separate bowl I mixed the cream of chicken, sour cream and more chili powder. I omitted the butter all together saving calories, and it won't be missed. Then I layered half the cream sauce on the bottom of the 9x13 inch pan and mixed the rest into the chicken mixture still in the crock pot. Then I placed a layer of tortillas (I used corn) in the pan, followed by the entire chicken mixture, cheese, another layer of tortillas, enchilada sauce, cheese, and olives. Prep time for the entire meal was 10 minutes. Trust me, you won't be disappointed! Next time I will use green enchilada sauce (personal preference for chicken.)

text:
This was incredible...everyone loved it! 

Oh, and I realized when I got home from the store that I forgot cream of chicken soup....so I consulted the interwebs and ended up with a great recipe to remedy that exact problem: 

I put three tablespoons of butter in a small pan, let it get nice and hot, whisked into it one or one and a half tablespoons of flour until it formed a nice roux....then I whisked in a half cup of chicken broth and a half cup of milk...and this made, to my surprise...an EXACT replica (except better) of campbells cream of chicken soup. It was so good, that I can honestly say I will quickly whip that together any time I find a recipe that calls for cream of chicken soup.

These enchiladas were super, super good. I LOVE enchiladas and these totally hit the spot and were exactly what you think of in your head, when you say to yourself "man, I'd love some enchiladas!"...GO FOR IT!

text:
Very good recipe - I would suggest grilling the chicken breasts on the gas grill instead of poaching them to give them a deeper flavor.  I also added about 1/2 teaspoon of ground cumin and 1/2 cup of salsa to the chicken mixture to take it up a notch.  If you have a gas stove, place the tortillas on the burner of the stove for about 20 seconds to gently char them before filling and rolling them.

text:
Really, really good!  You may THINK you don't have enough liquid while the mixture is simmering, but you will be wrong.  These were addictive.  Hint:  If you want to save time, you can pick apart a rotisserie chicken instead of shredding breasts, but shredding the meat really isn't as time-consuming as I thought it would be (about 10 minutes).  I also used double the enchilada sauce because I like to have extra, that was personal preference.

The enchilada filling was outstanding!!! But, make sure you use a good enchilada sauce, otherwise it will overpower the delicate chicken flavors. All in all, a great dish! UPDATE: I made just the filling (without the sour cream/cream of chicken soup/chili powder) for burritos, and they were AMAZING!!! Quick way to get the great flavor of this dish without having to go through all the steps of enchiladas.

None
text:
I give it 5 stars for ingredients but honestly think you are going through too much trouble.  I make a casserole instead of rolling out enchiladas since that adds more work AND if you do it casserole style, you get more servings out of it.  It tastes INCREDIBLY authentic this way as well.  The only ingredients I choose to use that are different is I omit the medium onion and olives and use corn tortillas instead of flour.  Here's how I do it.  I boil and shred the chicken and add it to all of the other ingredients into a bowl including half of the cheese and 1/4 enchilada sauce and mix together to make a "mix."  Take your casserole dish and coat the bottom of it with some enchilada sauce and set aside. I then scorch each tortilla one by one in a skillet on medium heat for with a little oil for 10 seconds or until soft and layer the bottom  of a casserole dish. Take the mixture, spread over the tortillas evenly and sprinkle with cheese.  Keep layering until you get to the top, cover with remaining green sauce and sprinkle with remaining cheese.  Cover dish with foil and pop into the oven!  25-30 minutes later you uncover and let it bake for about 5 more minutes to set.  THE END!

text:
This has been in my box for months and I finally made them yesterday.  It is a good recipe in many respects.  However, for the time it takes it doesn't deliver enough on flavor.  I followed others' advice and did the chicken in the crock with taco seasoning and with a 1/4 cup of jarred jalapenos in juice to up the flavor of the chicken which was excellent advice.  When simmering the chicken in the skillet, I replaced the water with a 16 oz jar of fire-roasted salsa and tossed in a can of corn for color and texture.  Given the amount of work that goes into it, we were expecting some knock-your-socks-off Mexican flavor.   Even with the onions, the chilies, all the seasonings, the salsa and the enchilada sauce, we all found it a little bland.   It was pleasant and I'm sure kids and those who don't like spice/heat would love it.  But if you're looking for a good solid spicy enchilada, you'll probably be a bit disappointed.

text:
Based on the reviews these enchiladas had been receiving I really expected more.  The first batch that I made were average, at best.  The flavor is not at all robust, it's sort of a generic tasting enchilada.  Perhaps something you might pick up at like a chain mexican restaurant.  I found that the recipe could be improved with about 1-2tsp of cumin thrown in with the chicken, as well as 2-3 cloves fresh garlic and a bit of extra chili powder.  These are then fantastic when topped off with a little green salsa and cilantro.  Also, I fried the enchiladas on both sides to crispy before I put them in the baking pan, it kept them from becoming too mushy.

text:
Wow... these were great! A bit time-consuming, but worth it. I used a half of a rotissiere chicken from the deli, which helped. I suggest before adding the enchilada sauce and cheese, spray the shells with cooking spray and bake on 425 for 10 minutes to crispen. I then added the sauce and cheese and finished baking at 350 for 15 minutes. I also added 1/4 tsp ground red pepper for a little heat... yum!

text:
I made these the other night to take to work and they were amazing! I pretty much followed the recipe, except that I used about half breast meat and half thigh meat. I also coated the meat in taco seasoning and browned it for a few minutes before boiling it. I used half water and half chicken broth to boil it in. Because I was making it to be eaten a few hours later, I was worried about it getting soggy. So I used corn tortillas instead. I also used only about half the soup mixture. I added about half the enchilada sauce when baking, and took along some more to be added when reheating them. There was no sogginess. I used smaller 5-inch tortillas and there was enough to make 20 enchiladas. One person even said they were the best thing he had ever eaten! Will definitely be adding these to my rotation! Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
For those of you wondering how much shredded chicken 2lbs is, here's the answer. I always poach (very soft boil) quite a bit of chicken at a time to freeze for the future. But it makes it hard to figure out what you need for a recipe!  For this recipe, you will need 3 1/2 cups of loose shredded chicken to equal the 2lbs needed. If you chop it up small it will only be about 3 cups.

The recipe is great as is. but my only major change I had to do is that it needs to be corn tortillas. I never ever ever use flour tortillas in enchiladas. Other than that the only thing i did different was when i boiled my chicken i used my own taco seasoning and only had 1 cup sour cream.

text:
I'm dissapointed!  I made this recipe just as wriiten.  I had expected from the "overwhelming" possitive ratings that it would be a 10!  To me (and my wife) it was pretty bad.  The ingredients were superb.  Actually the flavor was good.  The problem is that it became a cheese nightmare.  (That's coming from a Wisconsin boy).  There is way too much liquid in this to ever end up very good.  I was surprised at using flour tortillas to begin with.  All they do is soak up the enchilada sauce and all the cheese, they were a soaked mess.  The filling would be so much better if you stopped short of the (cream of chicken soup and sour cream).  Since trying it, I have really given thought to how you could make this better, I just can't without losing some key flavors. This recipe would be a better mexican dip than an entre.  Oh and the prep time estimate is right on, just add an extra hour for all the dirty dishes this creates.

text:
To give the chicken a nice flavor, if you are not fond of the "bland taste" boiled chicken has, I recommend taking the shredded chicken and mixing it with the taco seasoning packet and simmering it in the microwave in a covered dish for 2 minutes.  It helps marry a nice flavor to the chicken before continuing with the recipe... plus you are using the taco seasoning in this anyway. :O)  Hope you enjoy!

I really liked this recipe, I'm not one to cook a lot of Mexican but wanted to switch it up a bit.  I have a few family members who love Mexican and they pronounced this better than their favorite Mexican restaurants.  I thought the preparation was easy, and the ingredients were straight forward.  Don't get discouraged by the multiple steps - it ended up being a very simple process that looked more complicated. on paper than it was in reality.  The only change I would make is to find a good recipe for enchilada sauce, canned lacked in flavor and punch - it worked but homemade sauce would pull this together for me.

0
madeRecipesCount:
26
favoritesCount:
278
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/443298.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As I took my first bite, I was immediately transported to an authentic Mexican restaurant; I actually closed my eyes to savor it all.  My kids were thinking the same thing - as I was daydreaming, one of them piped up, "Now all we need is a basket of chips!"  I took a few shortcut suggestions from previous reviewers and did one thing on my own to make prep time quicker: I used both thigh and breast meat and let my food processor "shred" the chicken BEFORE cooking.  I then added about 1/4 c. or so of chicken broth to my frying pan and cooked the onions until pearly.  I then added the taco seasoning mix, onion/garlic/chili powders along with 1/2 tsp. of cumin and let that cook a few minutes to "open" the fragrances of the spices.  I then added the chicken along with the lime juice, green chiles and a small can of black beans.  I also made it layered a la Lasagna style since I was crunched for time.  It worked great!  I put 1/2 the chicken soup/sour cream as the bottom layer in the pan (I doubled both since I love the creaminess but make according to directions if you don't like that consistency).  Then I added a layer of the flour tortillas, the chicken mixture, enchilada sauce, and cheese.  I repeated it and topped with remaining cheese and baked on 375 for 50 minutes.  I used all low-and-no fat ingredients for the sour cream, soup, and cheeses and the flavor was still out of this world.  Served with shredded lettuce and Mexican rice.  Definitely a keeper and in "The" rotation.

text:
AMAZING!!! I followed the recipe EXACTLY as is and took this to my work for a going away pot luck, my point being that about 10 different people tried these and were blown away and asked for the recipe.  Okay, so I did change one thing, and that was using smaller tortillas so i could have several smaller enchiladas instead of 5 big ones. Either way, yummmmm yummmm! Made these twice in one week.  
MY ADVICE: Cook the chicken pieces whole and it does save you time shredding bigger pieces, and while the whole pieces are cooking, you can prep everything else.  It literally cut my total time in half.

text:
My hubby said, "This is AWESOME!"  He didn't even know the name of the recipe!  So there you go!  For me, this was comfort food for my little granddaughters, and that was my motive for using this recipe.  I did a couple of things I normally wouldn't have done.  I used a rotisserie chicken from Costco thinking it would save time.  But it really didn't.  And the white meat from the chicken breast would have been way better.  I used the Safeway brand of cream of chicken soup, and I didn't think it compared at all to Campbell's.  The recipe said that it served 8 but called for only 5 tortillas.  Still can't figure that one out.  I made 8-8" flour tortillas and still had the meat left over.  It was a mild, comforting recipe that I will probably make again but with a few changes (use the 7-oz can of green chilies, more than 3 cups of cheddar, a little spicier chile verde on the side).  Serve this with some Mexican Rice II from this site for sure!  All in all, a 5!  Thanks, Angela!

text:
Wow, I tried this with what I had on hand it was great.  Here are my changes based on the contents of the frig.  We like some spice at my house.  To the onions I added a tomatillo and a jalapeo (seeds and all) and a garlic clove.  After I pulled the chicken out of the water I let it keep boiling and reduce and added that water as my water for this recipe and the Spanish rice.  My husband will not eat sour cream =(  I did the unthinkable I subbed ricotta cheese.  Not as much but I added about a tablespoon of sour cream all I can get away with.  I hit it with a dash of white vinegar to sour it up a tad.  I had to do one more adjustment, I made taco season from a recipe on this site but it doesnt have the thickener that the store bought loaded with salt has.  So I added some File.  Its a decent thickener.  My hubby gave it a 9 of ten.    I really dont like using canned soup as they are really bad for you so I will try something else for that next time maybe a avocado puree or Spanish cheese sauce.  The tomatillo was a great addition and the pepper.  The cheese actually worked well but who knows what will be on hand next time.  Last thing, I use 3 boneless skinless chicken breasts from Sams and I had a lot of meat left over.  Next time two large ones are fine.

Display Name:
Angela

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/146.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe, but I have to admit...I didn't follow it exactly.  I didn't boil my chicken breasts, because you get so much more flavor from panfrying.  To cook chicken breasts, I sprinkle salt, pepper, and chili powder over both sides of chicken.  Fry them in vegetable oil and a pat of butter until lightly browned.  Meat does not have to be completely done.  Put breasts in a glass bowl with the juices from pan (deglazed by a little water).  Cover with foil and continue to cook in 350 degree oven while preparing the rest of the dish.  Sorry, but I didn't time it.  Also, instead of adding 1 cup of water, add enough water to chicken juices in the bowl to equal 1 cup.  Add that to the meat mixture instead of straight water.  I'm sure this recipe is much less healthful, but these simple steps add LOTS of flavor.  I fixed the recipe by the directions the first time, and everyone liked them.  The second time, I made it like I stated here, and my husband thought it was a completely different recipe.  He raved over it.  Even my PICKY kids loved them.

hnossa

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is now a standard recipe at our house.  I give it four stars and not five because I had to make a significant number of tweaks for this to be a keeper.  The first time I made this, I followed the recipe exactly, and ended up with a soggy horrible mess.  The sour cream sauce in the bottom of the pan turns the tortillas into muck.  So instead, I make a half batch of the sour cream sauce and add it all into the chicken mixture before filling the tortillas.  After the tortillas are filled, I bake them, without any sauce for twenty minutes, then cover with cheese and turn on the broiler until the cheese is bubbly and the tortillas begin to crisp up.  Then at serving, I spoon on green enchilada sauce.  Delicious!  I also use fresh chilies instead of canned, and use the juice of one whole lime (instead of just a teaspoon).  I think the extra lime adds so much great flavor!

Ohhhhh myyyyyy goooodnesssss, these were AWESOME, indeed!!!  I followed the recipe almost exactly.  I used a 2 lb. 10 oz. rotisserie chicken instead of boiling my own.  I also used queso fresco (next time I will try chihuahua cheese) instead of cheddar.  I was afraid the cheddar would be too oily/greasy.  And I used 1.5 cans enchilada sauce because I only had 10" tortillas and this recipe was enough to make 9 of those instead of 5 larger ones.  Anywho, these were awesome and everybody enjoyed them.  This is up there on my "the best thing I ever made" list. Absolutely amazing. I can't wait to have company over and make these for them!  Served with a side of spanish rice and some refried beans.

I SUGGEST MAKING THE "10 Minute Enchilada Sauce" from this site, absolutely amazing with these enchiladas, way better than store bought sauce!

text:
Loved this, and so did my entire family. Like another reviewer, I cooked my chicken breasts in the slow cooker (I used some all-purpose seasoning, an onion and 8 cloves of garlic, then shredded the chicken and saved the broth for another recipe). I subbed the sour cream for fat free plain yogurt, which was a great move! The sauce was AMAZING and my brother in law said it was his favorite dish I'd made... and he doesn't throw around compliments. I kept all the ingredients separate until 30 minutes before time to eat, so they never got mushy. I also did this for leftovers... I only cooked what we were about to eat, since the #1 complaint around here about enchiladas is the sogginess. Oh, I also made my own enchilada sauce (Red Enchilada Sauce off this site, but I added a little sugar and that helped the flavors come together somehow). Delicious!

My kids loved this recipe! Not too spicy but great flavor. I also used green sauce. Will use this one again for sure!

text:
I had been planning to cook this for a few days now and was really excited to impress my family.  I was nervous because we've been eating enchiladas at the same mexican restaurant for over 20 years and I knew this was going to be different, but hoped it would be as good.  I had read reviews about it being the tortillas getting soggy, so I mixed the chicken with all of the soup mixture early in the day, then just folded the tortillas and put them in the baking dish right before we wanted to eat, and topped that with enchilada sauce.  My family LOVED it!!  I should have put a little of the enchilada sauce or something down first, the bottoms were a little dry was the only advice I got from my testers.  Otherwise awesome!!  Everyone agreed it was a "repeat"!!  Thanks for the recipe!!

text:
These were better than in any restaurant I have ever went to.  I only did two things different.  I had made a pulled pork recipe from this site and had leftovers, so I used the pork!  DELICIOUS!  The other thing was that I only put the sour cream mixture (the one cup) in with the enchiladas and not at the bottom of the pan.  The inside of these enchiladas is SOOOO tasty!  The secret is in the seasonings!!! Thank you so much.  I can't wait to make them for my mother, the Enchilada Lover.
UPDATE:  This is still my favorite recipe and my mother asks for them all the time.  I quit putting the sour cream mixture inside the enchiladas and I go to the local store and picke up a rotisserie chicken.  This has cut the time in half and makes it an easy meal to make on a weekday/work day.  They still taste absolutely delicious.  I get the best raves about this recipe.

city:

country:

text:
These were great! I made only a couple of minor changes. First of all, I have two small shildren so I used five 6" flour tortillas rather than the 12" ones so that they would be smaller. I cut the recipe in half and used a square casserole dish rather than the 9 x 13 dish and they fit perfectly. Just line four of them up side by side at the top of the dish and lay the other one at the bottom going the other direction. The only thing I did differently was to drain my green chilies into the soup mixture and I omitted the black olives because I didn't have any on hand but will add them next time I make these. My hubby said these were even better than the ones at the Mexican restaurant we frequently go to. I served them with Spanish rice, Ranch beans and some fresh Pico de Gallo (also from this website) and, of course, chips and dip. This was my first attempt at enchiladas and I was very surprised at how easy it was. I will be making these again and again. Thanks for sharing!

First time making enchiladas, and the fam gobbled 'em right up! I cooked the chicken, taco seasoning and some water in a crock pot from nearly 3 hours, shredded it, then returned it to the crock, added the cream of chicken, squeezed the whole lime into the mix, then assembled the enchiladas without having any sauce on the bottom of the dish. I poured some enchilada sauce pver it, but saved about half the can to be poured on individually. I also topped with a TON of cheese. The fam wants this added to the regular rotation. :-)

These were really good! Putting half the soup mixture on the bottom of the pan makes the enchiladas more gooey than I prefer, but the flavors were excellent. I think the step of heating the soup, sour cream and chili powder separately from the chicken can be skipped. Next time I'll just throw the sour cream, soup and chili in to the chicken once it has finished simmering.

These are really fantastic!  I made mine with 1.25 lbs ground beef instead of chicken which made it really easy... at step 2 instead of using the butter to cook the onion I just added my raw beef and cooked it with the onion and two cloves of garlic (minced) until mostly browned, then seasoned with the taco seasoning, added the chilies, finished the browning of the beef, added the green onion, and water.  (Skip the extra onion powder and garlic powder, but be sure to add the lime juice!)  Proceed with the recipe as written... Great recipe!!

userID:
4908901
Display Name:
JoLScherer

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/690736.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were absolutely fabulous! I cooked the chicken in a crockpot in order to save a few steps. I used two large frozen restaurant style chicken breasts that I purchased in bulk at the warehouse store. Cut them in half, and they were still partially frozen when I placed them in a crockpot in the morning. I added the taco seasoning, onion powder, garlic powder, and chopped onions to the crockpot along with 3 TBS of lime juice. That may be a little too much lime flavor for some people, but either way, I've found that 3 TBS is all the amount of liquid that is needed to be added to the crockpot in the morning. By afternoon, there is the perfect amount of flavorful juices in the crockpot for the chicken to soak up once it is shredded and placed back into the crockpot. 
I then followed the recipe instructions for assembling the enchiladas and sauce. The only other substitution I made was to use a packaged Mexican 4-cheese blend instead just the cheddar cheese. 
I will definitely make these again! This is a great alternative to the much more difficult to prepare beef enchilada recipe that I had previously been using, but my family always requests. Thanks so much! Oh, I almost forgot to add that I used 8 inch tortilla shells instead of the 12 inch that the recipe called for and I got 10 enchiladas out of this recipe! Definitely a bonus! :)

text:
These are absolutely delicious. I've never had Chicken Enchiladas before, however, I think it would be difficult o find any better! My son, who is not much into spicy things, ate 3 of these. He liked them that much.    The only change I made was to use a homemade taco seasoning, as I had no package (1/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper, 1 teaspoon each garlic powder, chili powder and onion powder).   I think the cayenne added a bit of  kick as there was some extra heat in mine. Next time I'll try the Taco seasoning in the package.   These are not only delicious, they look really attractive. I am not someone who puts a lot into presentations and usually my meals don't look special. These looked really "pretty" and neat and something that would be good to serve to company :) I will make these often.  Next time, I plan on using smaller wraps and making a batch of mini enchiladas (I'm on a diet and a mini one would work).

text:
Our family LOVES this dish. We almost never have leftovers so I don't know how they would be as the next day's lunch although I'm guessing that, once cooked, they would freeze and reheat really well!  The first time I made it, I followed the recipe exactly and it was, as the name implies...Awesome!   On days that I know I'll be working late, I just put the raw chicken, onion, chiles, taco seasoning, water and a few green onions into the crock pot in the morning and let it cook all day.  Then when I get home, I shred the chicken, add the rest of the spices,  prepare the soup mixture and mix it all together & make enchiladas. It makes for a really quick and delicious dinner!

I wasn't sure how it was all going to taste since I didn't know what to expect from the sauce. Wow! was it good. My wife had seconds...not a common occurrence. I followed the directions to the T and didn't change or add anything except to use about twice as much enchilada sauce (good thing it was good!). We'll be eating enchiladas for a few days.

Update...made it again. This time I cooked the chicken in a crock pot and it was a snap to shred.

text:
These were really really good.  I made a couple of changes.  Even without these changes I think this would still be a 5 star.  I used boneless/ skinless chicken thighs instead of breast because I bought a bunch that were on sale.  Also, being a Texan I believe that enchiladas should be made with corn tort. not flour. I used 8 regular size tort. instead of 5 big ones. I just heated a non-stick small skillet on med.high heat and placed one tort. on there for about 10 seconds on each side to soften so they would not tear while rolling.  Other than that I followed the recipe.  I would for sure make these again as in two days my family ate them all.

userID:
10148158
Display Name:
sarahbear

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/909398.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this so many times, and they are so so sooo good! I get requests all the time to make enchiladas hahaha. A few things, I use about 10(taco sized)tortillas, 5 isn't nearly enough and they would be way to big. I also use reduced fat cream of chicken soup, and the last time I made it I used greek gods nonfat plain yogurt in place of sour cream, and it worked beautifully. I also add a minced garlic clove or 2 to the sauteing onion, and skip the onion and garlic powder. This recipe is easy to adjust to whats on hand, I often forget green onion and olives, while they are missed its still delicious. I've made it without the cream of chicken and sour cream when having guests who couldn't eat those things and it was still very good. I usually use a 7oz can of chillies instead of the 4oz because I like them, and to serve I top with pickled jalapenos, sour cream(greek yogurt)and guacamole if I have any avocados. ALSO! I love making a batch of the chicken mixture, then separating it into freezer bags and then when I want a quick easy meal? Pull out a bag, trow it in some tortillas with cheese and enchilada sauce, enchiladas ready for the oven in under 5 minutes, can't beat that. The mix is also good on nachos!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a truly awesome recipe, and the changes I made are mostly about personal taste. First, use more smaller tortillas and place them the other direction in the pan. Secondly, I added a 14.5 oz. can each of drained kernel corn and black beans to the chicken mixture to add a little counterpoint to the heavy creaminess of the soup/sour cream. Lastly, I made green enchilada sauce because I haven't found a good canned one. 1/2 C diced onion and 3 pressed garlic cloves sauted in 2 T oil. Add 3T flour, 1 1/2 C chicken broth, 2 4 0z. cans diced green chiles, 1 seeded and minced jalapeno, 1/4 t each of cumin and oregano, salt and pepper to taste. Simmer 1 hour.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious....I have never reviewed a recipe before but this is so good that I felt I had to review it.  I put the chicken and spices in my crock pot with 1/2 cup water.  After several hours I shredded the chicken.  It practically fell apart. Then added the soup, sour cream and lime juice.  Cooked for another 30 minutes on high.  I buttered a 9 X 13 baking dish and poured a bag of Frito corn chips in. Added a layer of frozen thawed corn and then a layer of drained black beans along with half the cheese.  I made the Red Enchilada sauce on this site.  After pouring in the chicken mixture I topped with cheese, a little more corn chips and the red enchilada sauce. The corn chips did not get soggy as I feared tortilla chips might.  Everyone loved it.

text:
Wow this is an awesome recipe, it is now our favorite enchiladas! I did notice that the brand of enchilada sauce you use will somewhat depend on how spicy it is, a real mexican sauce will be spicier then a name brand. It is okay to assemble them a few hours ahead of time n stick them in the fridge.The recipe is VERY flexible, I used a rotisserie chicken, skipped a few spices i did not have,neither did i add the water or lime juice or olives or onions in any form as I do not care for them. Even so it was a wonderful dish with lots of flavor!! All in all it's a super duper recipe that i would suggest this to everyone!!

These were awesome!!!  Takes a little time, but overall very easy to make.  Well worth the time it takes to prep everything.  You can cut down a lot on fat and calories with this recipe by using light/fat free ingredients without compromising the taste.  My husband always complains when I try to make something "healthier" and he didn't even notice.  This is now one of his favorite dishes.  Also, if you like things spicy, definitely increase the chili powder A LOT.  We used an entire pack of Buena Vista chili powder.

I have never reviewed a recipe on this site, however, these were BY FAR the BEST enchilida's I have ever tried!!!!! I have shredded beef, pork and chicken this way.  It works best when it is hot but works cold too.  Also this recipe is fantastic.  I used the packaged mexican shredded cheese with mine.  Next time i'm going to try corn tortillas since my husband prefers those.

text:
Made these last night with leftover rotisserie chicken...seemed a waste to not use it and save the poaching time.  I also used 5-inch corn tortillas (in Texas it is a burrito if wrapped in flour tortillas) and skipped the black olives.  I also used a dry enchilada sauce mix instead of the canned because I already had it.  My husband is a plain food guy, raised on the farm, who usually doesn't like anything other than straight up chicken (fried, baked, or roasted) and thinks enchiladas must have ground beef in them....until he tasted these.  I was resigned to having to eat all 16 enchiladas myself for the rest of the week (and then some) but he ate three helpings...and we even have rice and refried beans, not to mention chips and salsa to go along with them.  I will definitely make these again...but may try layering like a casserole next time.  This will be a great potluck or family reunion dish.

Believe the hype, these are awesome.  I made a 4 serving half batch...but, used 4 tortillas with approximately 1/2 cup filling in each.  I baked it in an 8x8" dish.  Was more than enough for 2 people.  I also used hot/spicy taco seasoning and it added more flavor and was not too spicy.

text:
OMG, OMG, OMG!!!!! These were every bit as AWESOME as their title implies! It is rare that I award 5 stars, but I just couldn't resist this time.... These are worth 500 stars, IMHO. :) Not only were these easy to throw together, they were absolutely delicious to boot. I've tried many enchilada recipes calling for cream soup and was never impressed with them. I couldn't even tell these were made with condensed soup! Other than speeding prep by subbing a rotisserie chicken (breast meat only), omitting the olives (my hubs and I don't like them), making only 4 enchiladas (all that would fit in my baking dish) and using 8 in. flour tortillas instead of the suggested 12 in. ones (personal preference), I made no changes. Served with Mexican rice, fiesta corn, chips, guacamole and margaritas. Thanks SO much for sharing your secret recipe, Angela. These were absolutely the BOMB! :-)

text:
These were DELICIOUS! I tried these and, as one poster recommended, put these ingredients in a crockpot with the chicken around noon and left it until about 5:30. The sauce itself was so delicious that I ate a bowl of it as soup while the chicken was still cooking! I didn't have any cumin :( 

Also, I added salsa con queso to the mixture in the last 30 minutes and it was divine! The shredded Mexican blend on top wasn't even needed! I wish I would've let the chicken simmer a bit longer, or even marinate overnight to better seal the flavor into it, but this was a GREAT recipe!

Display Name:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are the best enchiladas in the world!  I've made them several times just as the recipe says.  However, this time I made 2 slight changes.  I feel cooking and shredding the chicken is typically the most time consuming part, so instead I put 2 chicken breasts in the crock pot before I left for work this morning.  I covered them with water and added 2 tsp of chicken bouillon, and voila, the easiest to shred chicken when I got home from work to make dinner.  The second change I made was using 8" tortillas instead of 12".  I'm not quite sure how you are supposed to fit 5 12" filled tortillas in a 9x13 dish, but by using 5 8" tortillas I was able to use all the filling and fit them all in the 9x13 dish.  Hope these little tricks helps a few others!  It is definitely time consuming, but so worth it!

text:
So this recipe is phenomenal. However, I almost never go out of my way to have all of these ingredients on hand at one time, so I will share the changes I've used, which are still delicious (but I have done the original recipe, which is the one that claims phenomenalability).

Use cheese soup instead of cream of chicken soup, mix with the sour cream and chili powder. I used jalepenos instead of green chilies, left out the green onion and onion powder, and black olives. Once I cooked up the shredded chicken mixture, I added about half of the cheese soup mixture and mixed it with the chicken, as well as coating the pan, and once I had made up the enchiladas in the pan, I coated the top of the enchiladas with it too. (I looove that cheese soup mixture!) Salt and pepper it a little bit, perfecto.

None
text:
After many times making these, I put my own spin on this recipe. I use boneless, skinless thighs cooked and shredded in the crockpot. To the soup mixture, I add a LOT more chili powder, as well as garlic/onion powders, cumin, and even some enchilada sauce as well for additional flavor. I sautee my onion in a little butter, then add garlic, more chili powder and then the green chilies. I then add that to the chicken, and mix it well with the cup of the soup mixture. I don't measure out the cheese for the filling or the top, but just add until it looks like enough....too much cheese isn't a problem! I love this recipe overall, but just tweak slightly to make it easier on the preparation.

text:
I often roast a whole chicken in the slow cooker for dinner and make these enchiladas with the leftover chicken meat. Just throw the leftover meat in the slow cooker with a can of tomato sauce, a container of salsa and some chicken stock. Season to taste (I use cumin, chili powder, garlic powder, and a little salt). Cook on low 2-4 hours and then assemble enchiladas. Thanks for the great recipe!!

text:
So I think this is a great recipe.  I have made this a couple of times, the first time I followed the recipe to a T.  I really liked it and so did my family, but...I felt it was a little bit too salty for my taste and I like salt.  I'm not one of those finicky salt phobia types.  Anyways it has been awhile since I have made this but I had all of the ingredients on hand.  I would suggest and to save time make this when you have left over chicken.  We had a left over roast chicken, so I was able to skip the boiling part and just shred right away.  I also left out the green onions in step 2, mainly because we already heat up the chicken with a small diced onion already but I did put the green onion on top of the enchiladas before I put it in the oven.  Also I did not use all of the taco seasoning and in stead of filling each individual enchilada with cheese I just added cheese to the filling mixture and let it melt.  Its not major but some of these steps saved on some time and it turned out delicious.

text:

I would try medium enchilada sauce if I ever made this again. I would also smother them with picante sauce and guacamole.  Good recipe but not the best enchiladas that I ever had.

text:
My husband specifically requested I give these 5 stars.  He loved them.  He ate them for dinner, then lunch, then dinner again!  I had to adapt to what I had and I had to make them a bit less calories.  I used some frozen leftover cooked chicken, healthy request CoC soup, Light Sour cream, no butter at all, just some Pam spray,reduced sodium taco mix and probably 2 - 2.5 cups of cheese. Double lime.  Kids (3 & 5) thought they were too spicy  I also got 6 out of this recipe.  I left out the green onions, but only b/c I didn't have them.  Next time they will go in since this made the rotation.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
To save some time throw the chicken breasts in the slow cooker with just enough water to cover them, add some garlic powder, onion powder, salt and pepper, and let them cook on the lowest setting all day. They stay super juicy and shred easily. They are delicious as is, but a little on the mild side. If you like it a little spicier use medium taco seasoning, hot enchilada sauce, and add some fresh diced jalapenos in the soup mixture as well as on top.

Absoultely delicious! A little time-consuming, but so worth the wait. The filling was so good. I followed the recipe exactly as written, but omitted the olives (per preference) This by far exceeds any echilada recipe I've ever tasted. This will be printed and put in my recipe book! =)

text:
Very tasty! Did cook my chicken in the crockpot w/ some onions, abodo, and the green chiles in chicken stock, shredded like a dream. I also addded some cilantro because we love it. I must admit I am too lazy to roll enchiladas, so I did mine sort of chilequiles-style by cutting the tortillas into strips and toasing them for a couple minutes in the oven. I then layered everything  like a mexican lasagna instead of rolling.  Everyone was happy!!

I WISH that I could give this recipe more than 5 stars. I'd give it 10 if I could! There are so few recipes on here that are worthy of this kind of response. I love this recipe.  I will say though - only make this if you are committed to spending some time on supper.  It definitely is time consuming.  Not a quick supper to "whip up."  I made up the chicken and sauce the night before - then let it cook in the slow cooker while at work the next day and then I put it all together and baked when I got home.  Awesome taste - but I won't make it too often because it is definitely not healthy -- one of the worst I have ever made as far as that goes.  But sometimes you just gotta indulge.

text:
These were just great. Now I have my own special recipe that after 15 years never changed. I thought I would try something new for fun. Fun it was! Absolutely will do it again. One thing I did, also to add to being different was instead of rolling them into a enchilada I layered the tortillas flat. Used 8 in all. Spread the sauce as directed on the bottom, laid out the torts, spread the filling over them, topped with the cheese, then more flat tortillas, and then the sauce and more cheese. Wonderful stuff.

text:
I made this recipe using exactly the same ingredients, but followed another reviewer's suggestion to put it in the crock pot first.  It was really good, and all of my family loved it.  We actually discussed the texture of the chicken shredded vs. cut into chunks, and the consensus was that most of them preferred it shredded.  On that note, I have always shredded my chicken in my stand mixer (I have a KitchenAid).  Just throw the BOILED chicken in the bowl, and use the standard metal paddle to tear it up.  I timed it last night, and shredding the chicken took about 1 minute.  Easy peasy!  Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
Great recipe! I took another reviewer's advice and used the slow cooker.  I put 4 boneless breasts in there, along with the onion, taco seasoning, garlic & onion powders, chili powder, and about 1/3 c water.  I left it on low all day and then shredded it right in the pot.  I added the green chilis and soup mixture about 15 minutes before assembly and let it sit on high until ready.  I thought the amount of olives and green onions was a bit much so I used about half.

Display Name:
ali p

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had a few alterations. I only had 2 chicken breasts, so just used them. My chicken soup can was bigger than the recipe called for at 14oz. I used the whole can. I didn't have any green onions or lime juice so left them out. I used corn tortillas instead of flour tortillas. That was 11 corn tortillas (would have been 12 but the first one fell apart when i tried to fold it- definitely warm corn tortillas in the microwave with a damp paper towel over them for a minute before trying to fill/fold them) which filled up the big pan the recipe called for & a smaller square pan. I didn't measure the cheese, but just threw a bunch in and on top. My enchilada sauce can was WAY bigger (29.2 oz) but I used the whole can anyway. The results were good. The enchiladas were reportedly delicious (I'm vegetarian, so I can't personally vouch). They were mild though. If it were me, I would definitely add some spice (jalapenos maybe, or at the very least I would get the spicy taco mix and the spicy green chiles). Since the recipe yielded so many, my partner ate this for dinner the first night, then warmed it up the next night (still good). The next night we heated it up again & had friends come over to help eat it, & it still got rave reviews. Finally, the next night, my partner ate it again, & said it was still super delicious. It would probably be easier to shred the chicken if you left the breasts whole rather than cutting them up. Thanks!

I made this dish for dinner tonight for my husband, 16 year old son and 14 year old daughter, who are all very pick eaters and, they loved it!  It does take time to make but trust me, it's worth it. My daughter kept saying, "Mom, how come this is so good!" and my son said after he inhaled his second helping, "Good dinner Mom!" Pretty dang tasty!I've never made enchiladas before. I followed the recipe with a few exceptions that didn't affect the outcome adversely. I used the AR recipe for Creamed style Soup mix in place of the condensed soup. I also omitted the green onions and chopped green chilis. I used an AR recipe for Red Enchilada Sauce. I served this with Spanish rice. It seemed like a lot of work but dinner was delicious! Thanks for this awesome recipe!

None
text:
This was a great recipe after I made it much easier.  I did the following:  Combine 6 frozen chicken breasts, chili powder, onion, taco seasoning, 1/2 of water (instead of the cup of water), onion powder, and garlic powder in a crockpot on low for 8-10 hours.  When this is done, drain juices into a bowl for later.  Add the chicken soup, 3/4 cup of sour cream (instead of 1 1/4 - way too much)butter, chilies, onions, and lime juice - stir.  Add the saved juices as needed for desired consistency.  Then just follow the remaining directions on how to bake.  So much easier!!  And turned out fabulous!

text:
I took the advice of another reviewer and threw 3 frozen chicken breasts in the crock pot with all the powdered seasonings. This definitely saved time, but since I poured out the liquid that was formed when I went to shred the chicken, I think I lost too much of the seasoning with the liquid. Next time, I'll add a little more seasoning after I'm done shredding. I ended up putting these together in the afternoon and placing them in the fridge until I got home later that evening. I threw them in the oven for about 45min. and dinner was served. They tasted awesome (though, like I said, they needed some additional seasoning added). My son's had a slumber party that night and in the morning, they ate the leftover enchiladas for breakfast!

city:

country:
None
text:
My search for a great chicken enchilada recipe is at an end!!!  This is IT!  To some, this may look like a complicated recipe, but take the time to make it.  I promise you won't regret it.  I was asked "Why don't you own your own restaraunt?" when I served these.  They are THAT good!   I'm not a huge fan of boiled chicken, so here's what I did - substituted the boneless, skinless chicken breasts with split, bone-in chicken breasts.  Seasoned with a little taco seasoning, wrapped them loosely in foil and cooked in my slow cooker on low for 6-8 hours. When done, I took them out of the slow cooker and let them rest 20-30 minutes in the foil.  This made shredding them very easy. Fantastic recipe!

text:
Wonderful!!  I have never had enchiladas before and I wasn't sure what to expect.  My family loved them.  My husband said they were awesome.  I followed others suggestions and poached the chicken whole in the taco seasoning, onion, water and garlic and then shredded.  It was't too labor intensive done that way.  I then reserved the poaching sauce and followed the recipe from there, omiting the addition of the water later on since I saved the poaching water and spice.  I also added a can of black beans to the chicken just for added texture and flavor.  They were wonderful.  Thank you for a great recipe.

text:
These were outstanding! I used three pre-baked chicken breasts from my deli and used Monetary Jack cheese instead of cheddar. Next time I'll try with corn tortillas. Yum-o!---- UPDATE: You must try these with corn tortillas, they're so much better this way. P.S. You only use like half of the meat mixture so plan accordingly; you may want to double the sour cream/ cream of chicken mixture, buy extra cans of enchilada sauce and olives, and more green onions so you can double the recipe; you don't want to waste all that chicken mixture. Also, there is no need to shred the chicken with two forks, just use your fingers and save some time for crying out loud:)

text:
Didn't really care for these.  The sour cream and cream of chicken soup + chili powder didn't really "go" with these.  Also, I saw no need in heating that mixture.  I think you could just mix together in a bowl and add that way.  In addition, the chicken mixture was way too wet for an enchilada filling, so I ended up making this a layered casserole with lots of corn tortillas to try and absorb some of the moisture.  The taste was ho-hum, what I would equate to a Taco Bell version of "enchiladas"..  Being from TX, maybe I am just hard to please with Mexican food, but these just didn't really cut it.  My 3 yr old and I didn't like, but hubby seemed to think they were more thank okay..  Sorry, but I won't make these again.  There are several other enchilada recipes with "cream ofs" that taste MUCH better..

Use authentic Mexican cheese instead!


Not too bad. It's  loaded with onions thats for sure.  The key ingredient I changed was using Queso Fresco instead of any random cheddar or "mexican" Kraft cheese and it was for the same price. It made the enchiladas gooey inside without all the excess cheese grease from shredded cheese.

Made it for the family and friends for New Year's and it was loved.

text:
Excellent! I used 6 large chicken breasts cooked in a crock pot with chicken broth, bay leaves, onion flakes, lemon juice and pepper. I was able to make 7 very stuffed enchiladas using medium sizes flour tortillas. I would advise others to make sure you select an enchilada sauce that you really like. It will make or break this dish! I used 2 10oz cans of a mild sauce. Although it appeared like a lot of sauce it was perfect after it baked. Thank you for this recipe!

text:
These were delicious! My tweaks were minor--I didn't add more water to the shredded chicken because it was watery enough once I finished cooking it and I used 2 tablespoons of dried minced onion so I just added it to the shredded chicken mixture and didn't use butter. 

The biggest difference I ran into was that I couldn't fit 5 tortillas in my 9x13 pan (I guess I didn't wrap them tight enough). I use 4 tortillas as directed and then poured the remaining chicken mixture over the top of the tortillas. This allowed me to use the entire chicken mixture without using a second small baking dish. I then added the remaining ingredients as directed. A great meal!!!

Great recipe! Alot of prep time but worth it!

I made a couple small changes: seasoned and cooked the meat on an indoor grill rather than boiling it. Used corn tortillas rather than flour as I find they hold up to being soaked in sauce better, especially for the leftovers. I also added bell peppers as I felt it was lacking veggies. 

Will definitely make again using more veggies and make a bigger batch! My boys say it's definitely a keeper!! Thanks for the great recipe!!!

text:
My husband said it was delicious and I agree!  Made it with light sour cream and reduced the amount to 3/4 C and used low fat, low sodium soup. Added a pinch of cumin.  I didn't put cheese inside the enchiladas and only put 1/4 C of grated colby jack cheese on top which melted really well and spread out to cover each enchilada.  Also, I shredded 2 leftover grilled chicken breast (which was less than the called for 2 lbs). Used Pam spray in a non-stick pan to sautee white onion with 1/2 of a green & 1/2 of a red bell pepper. I didn't have green onions, black olives or onion powder. Four stars because the tortillas were really soggy. And that is after I toasted them on my gas stove top.  Overall.. excellent taste and I will try the crock pot suggestion to save time!  Thanks for sharing! I wish I was creative enough to come up with such a delish recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am not a terribly experienced cook, and I have come to realize that my food is not ever going to be very pretty.  That being said, sometimes I simplify recipes to make them easier for me to assemble.  In this case, I cooked the chicken, spices, peppers, and onions all day in the slow cooker.  I made the cream sauce and put some in the bottom of my baking dish.  I drained the liquid from the slow cooked chicken/spice/veggie mixture, then put it in my Kitchen Aid stand mixer to shred.  I added the remaining cream sauce and cheese shreds into the mixer as well.  No, it was not pretty, but it was much less messy to wrangle into tortillas and then into the baking dish.  Once baked with red sauce and more cheese, they didn't look too ugly.  I had more compliments on them than most dishes I've cooked for the family, and it was so easy to prepare.  I am making another batch today - one day after I made my first batch.  They were that popular!

userID:

Display Name:
Kimmy Wings

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4452419.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have never made enchiladas before - these turned out awesome!! My husband who grew up in a mexican town says they are REALLY good - not very authentic tasting, but he told me this recipe was a keeper. The only reason i'm giving it 4 stars is because I don't think it would have been nearly as good if I wouldn't have made some changes:
I doubled the recipe (mostly) - In a crockpot on high for 4 hrs i added water, packet of taco seasoning, 1 lb ground beef and 3 chicken breasts, along with dried pequin, serrano, and guajillo chiles. 
Instead of just sauting onion (used 3/4 of a red onion) - I also threw in 4 jalapeos, 1/2 green bell pepper, 3 garlic cloves, more of the pepper blend along with cumin, chili powder, oregano, paprika, blk peppercorns, and salt. I only used 1 bunch of green onions & 1 cup of water total for the recipe. 
The milk mixture - I used a little less sour cream, and 1 full tsp Chili Powder along with some spices listed above. I didn't measure out the cheese, just put on whatever. They turned out great  - just the right amount of spice and will definitely be making them again. I froze 3/4 of them - so hopefully they will turn out good when unthawed and reheated! Next time I will add the rest of the 28oz can of enchilada sauce (I only used 2/3 this time) and will stick with the same green chilis- 505 brand.

text:
I have made this recipe many times now.  The most recent time I omitted the cream of chicken soup (didn't have any on hand), and layered the tortillas, chicken mix and cheese and topped with enchilada sauce to make more of a mexican lasagna.  My family preferred this method as it was simply easier to prepare and eat.

These are fantastic.  I will be making again.  Just next time will use less cheese.  I'm a cheese guy but these are so good even w/o cheese I don't want to use much at all. Family loved it! Used cream of mushroom, instead of cream of chicken. Didn't use green onions or onion powder, because I didn't have any.
I didn't put the soup mixture on the bottom of the pan. I ended up mixing the entire soup mixture into the chicken mixture. I warmed up the tortillas a bit on a gas stove before filling them.
I doubled the recipe to fill 20 six inch tortillas and still had plenty of sauce leftover.
AMAZING!

text:
I've made this recipe for years with one basic change that doesn't altar the flavor, but makes it much quicker to put together. I put a small amount of soup mixture in the bottom of the dish and then layer the tortillas and chicken mixture. 
Another time saving tip is to make enough of the cooked chicken on a different night to have extra to make this dish. I usually do a broccoli/chicken dish on one night and have enough reserved chicken to use for this a day or so later in the week.
j

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic! My family loves these.  Makes 5 very well sized/stuffed enchiladas.  In some I add jalapenos inside and on the top for my heat lovers.  I have also cooked the chicken (whole boneless breasts) in a crockpot, with the taco seasoning and 1/2 C water, during the day while at work. When finished cooking the juices from the chicken with the water added to cook will yield pretty close to the 1 C called for in the recipe. Then I just shred the cooked chicken right in the crockpot, add the rest of the ingredients for the chicken mixture and let it cook for another 30 minutes or so while I make the soup mixture, preheat the oven, and get everything else ready to go. That's a real time saver!

text:
Wow!! Yes, you DO want to try this recipe!  It is amazingly good and easily adaptable to your family's tastes. I omitted the onion because my husband doesn't care for them. Although I love onions, I couldn't tell that they were missing.  I grilled the chicken and sprinkled it with the seasonings included in this recipe, plus a bit of cumin and some onion salt.  Next time I won't add additional salt because the taco seasoning has plenty.  I may try this in the slow cooker as another reviewer did, as it does take some time to prepare....but it's definitely worth the work. :)

text:
I left off the black olives and substituted corn tortillas, with only those two changes this recipe is exceptional. I couldn't get 12' corn tortillas, but the standard size corn tortillas worked fine. I had enough of the chicken filling mixture to make probably eleven enchiladas, but the 9" x 13' pan would hold only eight. Next time I will try browning the tortillas lightly, but I'm not sure that will be worth the extra time it will take to brown eight tortillas. Even though I didn't brown the tortillas for this first effort, the outcome was easily the best enchiladas I have ever eaten. Thanks a lot to MomSavedbyGrace!

text:
cook your chicken with seasonings and some chicken broth in the crock pot.  You will get far better results and shredding won't be as difficult.  2nd, I don't like to use taco seasoning as it's full of salt.  I mix my shredded chicken with sauteed onions, garlic, and jarred jalapenos with some softened cream cheese (4-8 oz depending on how much chicken you have) and generous amounts of cumin, some op/gp/pep.  For the sauce, similar to this, I mix 1 can cream of mushroom with 8oz sour cream, 1 cup milk, and a handful of chopped (jar) jalapenos. Pour sauce over enchiladas and bake 40 mins covered (we don't like red ench sauce).  Top with shred cheddar and bake until it melts.  I like to serve them with black beans.

Rating:
5

userID:
7102660
Display Name:
prplepumknetr
isPro:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6241429.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The only reason I am not giving this recipe 5 stars is because I had to make several adjustments to fit my taste. The cream of chicken mixture really makes this recipe a great success in my family.

1) I opted for traditional corn tortillas
2) I opted for a mixture of Monterey Jack cheese and queso fresco Mexicano
3) I used jalapeos for the chicken mixture
4) I skipped the olives and lime juice
5) To make the tortilla a bit more flavorful I dip each one in the enchilada sauce before stuffing and rolling
6) Lastly, I made my own enchilada sauce using a recipe on this site titled "ten minute enchilada sauce"

Thanks for sharing this recipe- always a hit!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2013-09-30T22:34:24.853
helpfulCount:
1
userID:

text:
This was the BEST recipe for enchiladas I've ever tasted! My husband really doesn't like trying new things and is very picky which annoys me bcuz he is the only one in our family of 5 that's like that. My son saw me make this and practically circled by the oven til it was done and refused waiting for it to cool off before he ate it. My whole family scarfed this down without chewing LOL. Even I was amazed on how delicious it was. My husband even asked me why hadn't I made this meal before. I will be making this often. The only thing I left out was the lime juice and black olives because I didn't have any and was NOT going on a grocery run and next time I will be using the low sodium taco seasoning. I also used whole wheat flour tortillas which there is no difference in taste then regular ones just a healthier version. It did not come out overly salty but just a tad. I think that simple change in taco seasoning will make it spectacular! I served it with Zatarain's spanish rice. This meal is DELICIOUS!!!!

This is a great recipe, but the first time I made it I noticed they were really soggy which my husband and I didn't care for. So now we just bake them and warm up the sauce in the saucepan. Then we put the sauce on top just before serving. This way they will not get soggy.

text:
I have made this for my family several times. Everyone loves it...even my two year old. Not two spicy, not bland. It is perfect as is. I have varied it some once in a while. This last time I added an onion and a stalk of celery to the whole breasts as they simmered. I had thought they would impart some flavor. They did, but not enough to warrant much improvement. The recipe is terrific as it is. I also use McCormick Enchilada Mix and tomato sauce and just follow those directions. We like that better than canned enchilada sauce. Whenever short on time though the canned works fine enough. I have also used a rotiserrie chicken and must say that does change the flavor a fair amount. I prefer it with just plain chicken breast. Thighs work great, too.

My family loves these enchiladas! Super easy to make, and you really can't go wrong...even if you don't have all the ingredients they will still turn out great. text:
This is a great recepe. I have been cooking Tex Mex for decades. This was a great recipe. In the preparation process I tasted bits and pieces as I went along. I was concerned it would be so-so. Only when the whole dish was all together did it really dance and sing with flavor and it did! I used a little more lime juice (tasted as I went along). Reading many reviews I thought of putting salsa in the cream of chicken sauce . . . but had none on hand, did have canned tomatoes with chilies, so I added half the can (7 oz.). Dont know if I will do that next time. This is a GREAT recipe. I did follow the review (voted most helpful) using a crock pot. Made the whole cooking process easier and most likely tastier.

text:
This was amazing!  My first time making chicken enchiladas and I wowed everyone!  I did make some minor adjustments.  I boiled a whole chicken, just a little over 5 lbs. with onions, garlic, rosemary, carrots and celery plus other spices to flavor up the chicken.  And I only used 3/4 cup of sour cream and added a handful or two of shredded mexican blend of cheeses as well as some Cholua sauce (can use tapito or Tabasco).  I also added the liquid from the chili to the onions while I sauteed the.   I will be making this again and again!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were pretty good. The taco seasoning overpowered it just a little bit, I'd like to have tasted more filling.

I would recommend using corn tortillas for a real good flavor. I used wheat instead, and it took away some taste (you really taste the wheat as opposed to flour).

I also used monterey jack cheese instead, cheddar is just too much for the dish in my opinion.

I heated the tortillas in a pan w a little enchilada sauce to cover the entire tortilla. Might have been a bad choice, was a bit soggy.

This made 8 enchiladas (big) using 12" tortillas. There's a lot of chicken filling! Depends on how much you plan to put inside, I suppose.

Pretty good, but I'd like to try a different enchilada sauce next time, I used Old Paso or El Paso whatever it is, and it wasn't very good.

The overall taste was pretty good, and I'll have to do some tweaking for next time.

I have wanted to make this for a long time, but was hesistant because of the length of time to make. But I had time yesterday. text:
Awesome!!!! I was a little worried about the cream of chicken soup and sour cream flavors, but it turned out great. I only made two small changes. I used corn tortillas instead of flour and added half a can of diced tomatoes & green chilies for a little more flavor to the meat mixture. These were even better the next day after all the flavors settled!

I've made this for the second time and cooking the chicken in the crockpot made the flavors really pop. I actually omited the butter this go around and only added the green onions on top. Cooking the meat in the crockpot is a MUST TRY...all I had to do was stir it with a fork and it fell apart.

text:
This is a great recipe.  I followed another persons idea to put the chicken in a crockpot with the taco seasoning, garlic powder, onion powder, chili powder, chopped onion, and I added a can of rotel original that morning. That afternoon the chicken was easily shredded.  I added the other filling ingredients to the crock pot and stir it up. Then I just assemble per the directions.  I then baked it for 40-45 mins.  I made some Mexican rice... wonderful!  Awesome recipe, my family stated that it was the best they ever ate, I agree.

text:
My husband and I LOVE this recipe!  We live overseas and are from California and desperately miss mexican food.  This is the closest to San Diego style enchiladas we've found.  We make a couple small changes: we only use enough of the sour cream/soup mixture to cover the bottom of the pan (we found that if we used what was left after adding it to the chicken mixture it caused the tortillas to get soggy) and we use corn instead of flour tortillas (our preference really).  It's a bit time consuming, but SO worth it!  Make these!  You won't be dissapointed!

text:
These were really, really good. I had never made enchiladas with the soup mixture in them, just chicken and cheese normally, so I was worried they would be runny...but don't skip the soup mixture! It gave a great texture to the enchiladas and kept the tortilla's moist. I used 10 tortillas, for 10 enchiladas. Not sure why the recipe says 5 tortillas for 8 servings. The seasonings and way the chicken mixture is prepared would be an excellent filling for tacos or burritos too. Great recipe Angela!

text:
Nice and easy recipe. I used 2 cans of soup and a little extra sour cream.  I don't care for enchilada sauce so I used a can of tomato soup and mixed it with salsa. Everyone loved it.  You can also easily make this with beef (I used ground beef one time and steak another and grilled pork another). Just substitute cream of mushroom soup for cream of chicken. I'm thinking of trying it with shrimp as well and maybe some cream of celery or the shrimp bisque soup. At any rate, it is easily adaptable and a crowd pleaser. I'm thinking it would be good with the reduced sodium soups since you have the taco seasoning in there too.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The technique to these seem to have a lot of work that doesn't seem necessary. I didn't bother with heating the sour cream and soup mixture. And I didn't even bother with the whole sauteeing of the onion. I just stirred everything together with about 3 cups of cooked chicken and added a can of black beans. I only added about 1/4 cup of water. 1 cup seemed way too much for me.  I used low-fat or non-fat options on the sour cream, soup and cheese. These are more like a "wet burrito" to me. The flour tortilla makes them more like a burrito. As for the flavor, they were good but nothing out of this world, nor would I probably make them again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made these last night and to say they were a hit would be an understatement. They were FABULOUS! I followed the recipe almost exactly (except had to substitute cream of mushroom soup for cream of chicken and regular taco seasoning for mild as this was all I had on hand).  Also, I was extremely low on time, so I only simmered for a few minutes after adding the taco seasoning - just enough to thicken it up and just a minute after adding the lime juice and spices.  I really don't think you need to simmer this for 10 minutes and then again for 10 minutes.  I loved the shredded chicken, but if I'm low on time again, I'll probably just cube the chicken very small after cooking.  All of my kids devoured this!

text:
I've always been skeptical of enchiladas made with cream of chicken soup, but this recipe had so many good reviews, I decided to give it a try. Glad I did.  Outstanding!  Only 2 changes: used corn tortillas, quickly fried first, and used a larger can of enchilada sauce, because that's what I had on hand.  To those who say this recipe is labor intensive, I've not found a good enchilada recipe yet that doesn't take the better part of an afternoon to make; this recipe is well worth it.

country:

text:
I made this recipe as-is, only using low-fat sour cream and healthy request cream of chicken soup.  And just 2 cups of cheddar instead of 2.  I thought it tasted very rich even with these substitutions.  Very tasty, although a bit too sour creamy for my palate.  People who like sour cream will really like this.  For those that don't, I would advise just using maybe half the sour cream, and mixing it with more enchilada sauce instead of the cream of chicken soup.  The chicken mixture was quite good I thought.  I also cooked this at 400 degrees instead of 350 and it browned up nicely on the top.

Exellent-- just a thought for weight watchers like me that love mexican---even lower fat and calorie version--- Use no salt or low fat cream of chicken soup Use 0% Greek yogurt instead of sour cream make your own taco seasoning use fresh garlic and onion rather than powder use fresh tomatoes rather than enchalada sauce 2% chedar cheese fresh chilies rather than canned serve with avocado slices I did this substitution but followed the recipe --- Everyone loved it---thank you!!

We really enjoyed this recipe!  I did make a couple of adjustments due to my husband's poor grocery shopping abilities:  I used green chile enchilada sauce instead of red, and I also was forced to omit the green onion and green chilis...because he didn't bring them home. But, all in all, this recipe was AWESOME!!!

text:
A delicous and pretty easy chicken enchilada recipe.  I used boneless chicken breasts the first time, then used shredded chicken meat from a whole chicken that I had in the freezer the 2nd time (much quicker to have chicken already cooked and shredded).  I followed the recipe exactly as indicated, but I added an extra can of olives on top because my family loves olives!  We have added this recipe to the list of good 'ol standby recipes!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Healthy version (well, as healthy as it can be!):  Use the Ezeckial 4:16 6" tortillas.  Use 2 chicken breasts and 1-2 cans drained, rinsed black beans.  Use 2 cups of cheese.  To add more flavor so it is perfect: add 1 teaspoon cumin in step 1, 3/4 teaspoon garlic powder and some addional fresh garlic to step 1, and a 1/2 cup salsa to the chicken mixture in step 2.   Also, omit the green onions entirely (I did put them in there, but couldn't taste them or their texture at all).  I made 12 6" tortillas out of the full recipe.  I froze 5, and baked 7.  IT WAS SOOOOOOOOO GOOOOOODDDD!!!! ENJOY!

text:
I made this tonight for dinner.  My husband said these are better than restaurant quality!  I used corn tortillas instead of flour.  Corn tend to crack a bit when you put the meat and cheese into them but once you add the enchilada sauce and cheese and toppings in the baking dish, it all blends together perfectly.  I would make this over and over again as well as serve it at a dinner party.  I bet you can make these ahead and throw them in the oven 45 minutes before serving.

country:
None
text:
These were really good.  I had some leftover chicken from the Simple Roast Chicken recipe on this site so I used that and I added one shredded boiled chicken breast- it probably wasn't quite 2lbs of meat, but I kept all of the other ingredient amounts the same and it worked fine.  I made a few modifications based on what I had in my pantry- instead of green chilies I used chopped jalapenos.  I didn't have the green onions or black olives so I omitted those and I added sliced jalapenos on top.  I also added about 1Tbsp of minced garlic to the chicken mixture when I added the garlic powder.  My husband and I both loved these.  They were quite a bit of trouble to fix, so I'll probably save them for special occasions when I have more time to cook, though.

My family is partial to the white/creamy type chicken enchiladas; so they were hesitant when I served these up. Thankfully everyone was pleased with them! city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is simply unbeatable for delicious Mexican food made at homeIm not even a fan of enchiladas and never order them in a restaurant, but I love this dish!  So does everyone I have ever made it for. It does take a while to assemble, but is absolutely worth it. I make it as written, but Ive found that if I double the sauce and chicken mixture parts, I end up with a enough final filling mixture that I can make 4-5 large enchiladas and save half of the filling and freeze it in a zip lock bag for another time. Its then fairly quick to heat up a single batch of the sauce (soup, sour cream & chili powder), fill the tortillas with the thawed mixture and bake.

country:
None
text:
We love Mexican dishes so this was a hit with my teenage boys. I will tweak it a little next time by adding only 1 cup of sour cream to the soup mixture. It was super rich. Since my boys dont like olives Id probably top with some diced tomatoes in place of olives. I also think you could get by without the soup in the bottom of the baking dish because that makes it a little too mushy for me. I had a couple extra tortillas and chicken mixture leftover so I made two more enchiladas and put them in another dish with some enchilada sauce on the bottom instead of the soup and I think they turned out better. Very good recipe even if you dont change anything!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a terrific recipe! Very delicious, and easy and fast with a few shortcuts. 1) Use a rotisserie chicken from the grocery store. 2)Rather than making individual rolled nchiladas, layer the ingredients as a lasagne - 1/3 of the sauce, tortillas pieced to cover the bottom of the dish, 1/2 the chicken mixture, 1/3 of the cheese.  Repeat. Cover the top with a pieced layer of tortillas, spread with remaining sauce and then cheese. Other than the layering and rotisserie chicken, use and mix the ingredients in the recipe, and bake as directed. Great company meal served with Spanish rice, the Mexican Bean Salad, and Mexican Hot Chocolate Cookies (the last two from the site)!  Thank you, Angela!

region:

country:
None
text:
The enchiladas were delicious!! My husband that doesnt care for Mexican cuisine enjoyed it and my toddler loved it! I made a few unnecessary changes but did so for my own convenience and preference. I used a rotisserie chicken that I deboned and removed the skin that I slightly seasoned with season all then shredded. This gave me more than enough shredded chicken and allowed me to freeze the remainder for a later time. I also used the Mexican blends and Cheddar blends of shredded cheese instead of just plain cheddar. I eliminated the black olives. I also used just a hint of cinnamon in the chicken blend for a savory kick. Definitely give this recipe a try.

text:
Followed the recipe but used 9" soft taco flour tortillas (not 12" since unavailable and they would not fit in a 9" wide pan anyway) and green enchilada sauce. When using 9" tortillas, 6 fit in the 9" x 13" pan for me. One enchilada is very filling.  I love enchiladas and wanted to love this recipe but it was not great at all. Using corn tortillas would have probably worked way better. The flavor was okay but the recipe didn't need that much soup mixture at all, maybe half that amount could have worked.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Needed a minor re-write to make sense.  Step 1 needs to be modified, add:  Save 1 cup of water used to boil chicken as broth.
Step 2. Combine cream of chicken soup, 1 cup of saved broth, sour cream, chili powder, simmer on low heat.  
If no liquid is added to that thick base of cream soup/sour cream, there will be thick lava bubble explosions.
A note on tortilla choices, white flour will have a slimy texture when done, due to gelatin effect.  Try corn tortillas that absorb liquid better, as an option.

Love this recipe. I substitute 1/2 of the chicken with zucchini and/or yellow squash. I put the squashes in with the butter a couple minutes before adding the onions. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is real "soul food" here in California and yes, I will definitely make this again.  I did make some changes and they are as follows:
Instead of 2 pounds of chicken breast, I used only one half of a whole chicken breast and I pre-cooked the frozen breast  in the Instant Pot with a cup and a half of water for 35 minutes.   Used Monterrey Jack as well as Cheddar cheese.   Used Hatch Green Chile Salsa in a jar instead of red enchilada sauce in a can.   Lastly, I used a recipe for taco seasoning mix that I make myself taken from a cookbook titled "The weeknight DINNER Cookbook" by Mary Younkin,  pg 158 called Mexican Seasoning Mix which I used by seasoning to taste.  My only regret is that I was only able to eat one enchilada.  Refrigerated the rest for later.  I had to talk myself out of over-eating on this one.  Made enough for 5 large enchiladas.

country:
None
text:
I made these trying the suggested slow cooker method (chicken stock, enchilada seasoning pk & diced onion). After work I shredded the meat only to find the flavor was lacking, so I followed the remainder of the directions to the T topping it w/10 minute enchilada sauce from this site (added a dash of cocoa powder). My family has a new favorite for the rotation.  For this being my first attempt at enchiladas.... I just WOW'd myself & the hub's :)  Thank You Angie!
Quick suggestion: dip the outer side of the shells (I used 6" corn) in the enchilada sauce quick and it won't tear when you're rolling it.

This is the absolute best enchilada recipe! The only changes I've made is that I use a Costco roasted chicken in place of cooking a chicken. I also substitute a large can of green enchilada sauce and add 3/4 of it to the sour cream mixture (reserving the last 1/4 for topping). 
These enchiladas are mouth-watering delicious and  worth every calorie!

text:
Very good, but not fast. Made the chicken in the instant pot after marinating in some yummy Mexican spices. Shredded it. Still took an hour from start (sauteing the onions, once I added the chicken, I started the soup/sour cream) to finish. Somewhat intensive, but the flavors were great! Everyone liked it! Did use green enchilada sauce because I bought the wrong sized red one. The boys really liked it. Will make again, when there is time.
