text:
Well,  I'll definitely be making this again for the family!  My husband loved it and said it tasted like something from a restaurant.  I skipped some steps and just went straight to cooking the chicken in some water with the taco seasoning, chili powder, garlic powder, onion powder and  onions.  Once I simmered for a while, I shredded my chicken and added back into the skillet.  Once done, I added the other ingredients following the directions from the recipe.  Paired this with the Mexican Rice 2 from this site.  Will definitely make again.  Thank you for a wonderful recipe the whole family can enjoy!

text:
This recipe was delicious! Instead of putting some of the enchilada mixture on the bottom of the pan, I put about 1/2 cup of the enchilada sauce on the bottom of the pan and filled about 6 extra large tortillas with the mixture. I poured the rest of the enchilada sauce over the top and covered it with cheese. I didnt have regular onion so I sauted green onions and used olive oil vs butter. I added black beans to the soup mixture too and it was delish! Ill definitely be making this recipe again!

text:
Great recipe - I liked having the creamy soup, onion and chicken mixture inside made for a nice contrast to the enchilada sauce on the outside. 

To keep my corn tortillas from cracking, I heated them in a plastic bag in the microwave for 20 seconds, and then also heated them in a hot pan with oil for another 10 seconds per side, holding them in foil wrap until I was ready for them - perfect no breakage!

text:
To simplify things, I cooked the chicken in my instant pot and shredded it with a hand mixer.  Then I mixed sauteed onions and the seasonings in. Despite this, I thought this recipe was not worth the amount of work and dirty dishes.  While the taste of the chicken mixture was probably 4 stars, I've had similar filling that took less ingredients and effort.  I really disliked how soggy the soup/sour cream mixture made the enchiladas and found the texture of the final product somewhat revolting.  My husband thought it had 4 star flavor.

text:
We have a family member that does not like certain veggies so I did not use the black olives, green onion and chili peppers.  We like things spicy so I used 1 1/2 teaspoons of chili powder versus 1/4 teaspoon as called for in the recipe.  I noted some saying the mixture was too 'soupy' so I was  very sparing with the fluids used.  Used the left over broth from cooking my fresh chicken breasts instead of water.  My family LOVED this.  Oh.My.God.  I had a 4 year old grandson and a 9 year old grandson cleaning their plates and asking for more!  I thought I might have some leftovers....  ummmm not really.  Just a little dab leftover just  enough for a snack.  This recipe was served alongside  Refried Beans and Mexican Rice topped with cheese.  EXCELLENT MEAL ! btw the pickiest family member (our adult son )who doesn't like pepper or onion type veggies gave me the best compliment....I got a 'mom you ARE going to make this again aren't you?

text:
I followed one reviewers  suggestions by making the chicken in the crock pot and then combining everything into the crock pot. That cut down a lot on the time and was super easy to do. I don't think there would be much of a flavor difference doing it the way it is suggested in the recipe.

As far as the taste goes, I think these did taste a bit generic. Kind of like going to chain Mexican restaurant. They were good, but nothing I would rave about. The biggest disappoint was the tortillas. They were super mushy, kind of like raw dough.  If I tried this recipe again, I would probably try frying them like someone suggested.

This recipe was easy and excellent.  I didn't boil my chicken, I had frozen chicken thighs that I threw in a crock pot with taco seasoning and salsa for 5 hours and then shredded it.  I did all of the rest in a single pot to save time.  4 out of 5 kids even ate it so I consider that a huge success!  Very easy and will make again.

text:
My teenage son would eat these for every meal of every day! Typically, he hates having his food touch but these are his favorite meal! I cook the chicken, taco seasoning, water & all spices in the crockpot for 4-5 hours on low in the morning as a timesaver. When I get home from work, I shred the chicken and mix the remaining ingredients in the crockpot.  I probably use double the cheese but that's because we're a cheese-loving family! Other than adding the extra cheese and a tablespoon of ground cayenne pepper (because we're also a spice-loving family!), I use the same ingredients just prepared a little different for time. Thanks for a great recipe!!

I made some changes...corn tortillas instead of flour, previous nights leftover grilled (hickory wood) chicken, Monterrey cheese instead of cheddar, and green enchilada sauce instead of red.  That said, I followed the directions made these minor changes to the ingredients and "voila"  good enchiladas.  Homemade Serrano pepper salsa for my kick. my dinner guests dipped in for seconds.  Will make this recipe again.  Thanks Angela!

I don't think 5 stars is enough.  I have made these so many times.  It is a household favorite.  I made them for my husband's 50th birthday...and had guests asking for the recipe.  I made them and froze them (before cooking) for my daughter when she had her baby.  That had her asking for the recipe.  She then made them for someone....more recipe requests. You won't go wrong with this recipe.

text:
This was okay but nothing special. The enchiladas were slightly bitter from the sauce, could have used something to counterbalance that.

The skillet I was using was a bit too small for all the ingredients, next time I'd use a pot of some kind. Similarly, the baking sheet was too small to comfortably hold all my enchiladas. Next time I'd split them over two. 

I substituted onion powder for the onion, chopped olives for sliced (wouldn't do that one again) and used slightly more chicken. It's possible that somehow screwed up the flavor of the dish.

text:
So there were a things I didn't have. Like the green onion, the sour cream, and the olives (which I hated anyways) I only used a lb of chicken because there was only two of us. Instead of the sour cream I used a splash of milk. When boiling the chicken (since I loathe boiled chicken in water) I threw in some bullion cubes to help with flavor. Added extra dashes of all the powders and even some cayenne for a kick. (Sorry, one of those people who edits along the way!) Made some rice with sazon in it, spooned some rice into the tortillas and it came out better than I thought. It was so good.

text:
This was flavorful for the minimal amount of effort required. I made a few changes based on what I had off hand. It was a great use of the left overs from a roasted chicken I made two days ago. I didn't have sour cream so I used 1 C. Plain Yogurt and 1/4 c.  Milk as substitute. The consistency wasn't as thick but the flavor was good. The additional spices balanced nicely with the tang of the yogurt. I also used a 4 oz can of diced Tomatoes & Green Chiles. I like that I was able to play around with the recipe and it still came out great!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/862162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Omg we loved this recipe.  We can't leave recipes alone so we did change a couple of things.  I feel like they weren't critical to the integrity of the recipe.  Our changes were merely to taste and what was accessible, so I'm still rating this five stars.  

Our changes were to leave out the olives.  I swapped cheddar out and Monterray Jack in.  I also cooked my chicken in the crockpot ahead of time in one cup of water with onions and spices.  Once the chicken (half thighs half breast) was cooked, I drained the liquid and made homemade cream of chicken.  1tbsp butter, 1tbsp flour, 1 cup of reserved cooking liquid plus whatever extra for desired thickness.  No milk because there's already a cup and a quarter of sour cream.  It came together perfectly!

text:
Yum, yum yum!!!
I followed this recipe to a T, with one small exception.  I didn't have any packaged taco seasoning on hand so attempted to fake my own with cumin, coriander and chili powder.  I also boiled whole chicken breasts in water seasoned with extra cumin, chili powder and lime juice before shredding the meat.
Super pleased with how these turned out and will definitely make these again!  My only (minor) complaint was that the flour tortillas were a tad bit gummy.  May try to crisp them a bit in a little bit of hot oil next time.  I also wouldn't mind a bit more red sauce but that's probably just me.
Thanks for sharing!

country:
None
text:
Excellent and a crowd pleaser!

I followed the recipe exactly with just just 2 small changes.  I substituted corn tortillas for flour.  I have made enchiladas the traditional way for many years and I don't like the "gummy" texture flour tortillas can get when baked in sauce. Just my personal taste/opinion. I also poached bone-in chicken breasts rather than boneless. Better flavor in my opinion :)
This isn't an "authentic" type of enchilada, but it's very tasty and the milder, creamier sauce appeals to those who may not like the traditional spicy "red sauce" enchiladas.  I make a big pan for company on "Football" Sundays and there are NEVER any leftovers!

text:
Best enchiladas I've ever made. Unlike other enchiladas, they were not wet. When cooking, the "simmer" step should be "saute", because there is very little water at that point. If you don't keep stirring, the chicken will burn. This step puts a delicious brown on the shredded chicken and brings out the seasoning flavor. Very tasty!

text:
I made the Angela's Chicken Enchilada's last weekend & they were a rousing success.  Both my adult children & I loved them & I followed the recipe exactly as is my usual method with a new recipe.

I've made Mexican Dishes since my Air Force days in San Antonio, TX. "long ago" where I was taught by a lovely, very old Mexican Lady.  Neither of us spoke the others language but we found we did not find that a barrier.  I taught her to make several strictly Southern dishes---"Creamed Corn, Corn Bread, Biscuits, etc."  We had a  lovely relationship---soo, Angela's recipe is very good & my friend would enjoy it.

Thank you Angela!

text:
I have my own "famous" chicken enchilada recipe, so I rarely try any others. However, i decided to branch out and try this one since the reviews were great. I can say...the almost five-star rating was well-deserved. I followed the recipe to the "t" but will make one change for next time...next time I will add my enchilada sauce to the remaining soup/sour cream mixture and put some on the bottom of the pan and the rest covering the enchiladas. I think that will mellow out the enchilada sauce a little more. Overall, this is an awesome recipe I will be making again. My kids all loved it!

text:
This recipe was amazing!   I typically don't say that about most recipes, but this one definitely was.  The changes I made were putting everything in the slow cooker minus the cheese and sauce.  I don't have a stove top right now, so had to get creative.  I didn't use the chives and butter.  I used half and half of the mild and hot/spicy taco seasoning.  I used mozzarella with mild cheese.  I picked up the wrong enchilada sauce--used green instead of red.    I put the whole chicken breast with the mixture (chx soup, sour cream, water, spices, and seasoning).  My slow cooker had the chicken cooked in 2-3 hours on low and I shredded it and put on warm.  I followed the instructions--put the mixture on bottom with some cheese, wrapped the tortilla, topped with sauce, cheese, and olives. I did bake it at the instructions,  however, the last 10 min or so I broiled it at 350.  Probably won't do that again.  Don't think it made a difference.  I thought this recipe was excellent and loved it.  Can't wait to make it again!  This time with red sauce.

text:
Great recipe! Everyone I have made these for love them! I do make homemade red enchilada sauce I found on another recipe here (10 minute enchilada sauce). I do use smaller white corn tortillas just as a personal preference. It takes a bit more time rolling them. But it's worth it in my opinion. If you choose to use corn tortillas, pop them in the microwave for about 30 seconds before rolling. They won't split this way. I also added a bit more taco seasoning. The filling is also great in quesadillas. Enjoy! Thank for the recipe!

I always make them exactly how the recipe is made, the only exception being (to save time) is buy a fully cooked rotisserie chicken at the grocery store and shred that.  Wonderful!  Thanks so much for sharing this recipe!

text:
I followed the recipe exactly, except that I had chicken breast meat left over from a rotisserie chicken, so I didn't have 2 pounds.  I also crammed 10 enchiladas, not 5, into a 9" x 13" pan, and had plenty of filling for all of them. I took the dish to a potluck, and there was only a tiny bit left, so I'd say it was a hit! The only change I would make the next time I make this (and there WILL be a next time!) is to use a little more enchilada sauce over the top of the enchiladas. A 10 ounce can was not quite enough to cover all the tortillas.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for 80 people and everyone loved it. Since I was making so many I made half of them with flour tortillas and green verde sauce and the remainder with corn tortillas and red sauce. I greased the pan and did not put the sour cream mixture on the bottom of the pan because I didn't want them to be soggy on the bottom. Otherwise I made them as written and next time I'll use half of the sour cream mixture to add to chicken base. Forgot to mention that I bought Costco's cooked rotisserie chicken breast and add the ingredients the night before so the chicken could absorb the flavors. It was easy and very very good. The green chilies added some heat. The most time consuming part was shredding all that chicken, in my case 20 pounds in all. Will make again!

text:
Best enchiladas we've ever had at home. We like them a little crispy, so I added most of the chicken soup mixture directly to the chicken vs the bottom of the pan. Also cut calories using plain Greek yogurt in place of the sour cream. We love bold flavors as well and adter reading some of the other reviews in place of the water, I added a diced tomatoes with chili's, half a jar of salsa, and half of the enchilada sauce. So amazingly delicious!!!!!

text:
I've made this dish dozens of times.  It's one of my family's favorite meals.  I've played with the recipe quite a bit over the years and crank up the spice a little bit by adding a few chipotle peppers, chopped up fine, and added with the chili's.  A few peppers go a long way so don't over due it!  I also add a generous dose of chili powder to the cream of chicken/sour cream mixture.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
MOST FLAVORFUL enchiladas we've ever had! Just tweaked a tiny bit to ensure meat was flavorful based on other reviews. Sprinkled some of the taco mix, a little chili powder (still added the normal chili power the recipe called for - this was just a little extra to coat the breasts), salt, and pepper on each side of chicken breast. Browned them in a pat of butter, deglazed pan with water. Added this liquid to the chicken breasts, cover w/ foil, and put in oven at 350 to finish cooking while preparing the rest of the recipe. After I shredded the meat, added what the recipe called for plus 1/2 tsp. cumin. Instead of water, used 1/2 c. of the liquid from chicken breasts and 1/2 c. salsa to add to shredded chicken. Meat was sensationally seasoned and NOT bland. Great flavors!!

text:
I don't think I have ever rated a recipe on this site, however, this one deserves a five start rating.  It is beyond fantastic!  I will definitely be making this again.  Not sure what some of the other reviewers were saying about it being too cheesy or soupy.  It was restaurant-quality flavor.  I made the recipe exactly how the author wrote it and it was FABULOUS!  Definitely give this recipe a try.  I made no substitutions or changes, and I am so glad I didn't.  I used Mission brand tortillas and Ortega brand mild enchilada sauce and taco seasoning.  I did not use the Healthy Request cream of chicken soup, just the regular Campbell's cream of chicken soup.  It said it was already low in fat.  The recipe does take some time, but it is worth it.  Well done Angela on these Awesome enchiladas!

text:
These were Awesome!  I made half GF with corn tortillas and half not with flour.  We will definitely use this recipe again.  A nice mix between white and red enchiladas.  To get a jump on making this you can boil the chicken earlier in the day then drain the water and put the whole chicken breasts directly in your kitchen aid mixer with the paddle attachment.  Turn it on and the chicken will shred on its own! Big time saver!

text:
Very Good..  Making shredded chicken is a must, just don't boil or overcook the meat or it will be tough.  I followed the recipe as is except I don't use canned soup.  Just put 1/2 tbs. of flour and 1 tbs. butter in the pan until melted then add 1/2 cup chicken broth and 1/2 cup of milk or half and half and simmer until thick.  I don't care for enchilada sauce so I just use salsa on top.. My kids said the leftovers were even better reheated the next day.  Thank you..

userID:
12388231
Display Name:
Lisa Duetsch
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
17
favoritesCount:
540
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6429339.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
4 stars as written, since I think this would be much too bland for us, 5 stars with a few tweeks to amp up the flavor and heat.  I assembled this a day in advance, and sent it with my husband and BIL for their guys' weekend.  Hubby mentioned that BIL declared them the best enchiladas he'd ever had. You can't argue with that.  My changes:

Use 1 small can of HOT green chiles, plus 3/4 can of chopped (or 1 fresh) jalapenos.  Used approx 12oz of enchilada sauce.  I also added 3 garlic cloves, 2 tsps cumin to the sauce and doubled the chili powder.  Cut the cheese to about 2 cups.  I used small ~5" corn tortillas that I seared in a dry pan over high heat (worried about them getting soggy due to the advance assembly).  Serve with additional sour cream and salsa.

I finely chopped vacuum-packed rotisserie chicken breast pieces from the warehouse store because I had some, but would like to try the crockpot method next time.  Shredding meat is quicker than chopping...

The filling made about 20 5" corn tortillas.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2015-07-14T15:31:46.437

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious!  I wanted this for a week-night dinner and decided to make a couple of changes.  Rather than cooking my own chicken breast, I got a Costco roast chicken and just chopped the breast and leg meat from that to use.  I realized I didn't have cream of chicken soup, so I used cream of celery (which sounds weird, but  was actually good).  Also used fat free sour cream, whole wheat reduced fat tortillas, and reduced fat cheddar cheese, only using 2 C of cheese rather than 3 to try and reduce calories.  My kids and husband are picky, but they all really liked it.  I will definitely make this again.

text:
This was an excellent recipe! Normally I look at the ingredients and time it takes to make something before I start.  Well, I noticed I had all the ingredients and got excited and totally forgot to check the prep/cook time.  It is accurate.  It took forever. But WORTH it.  I didn't have a can of cream of chicken so I made my own (EASY: 1Tbsp butter, 3Tbsp flour, 1/2C milk, 1/2C chicken broth) and I substituted the sour cream with plain greek yogurt. Also no olives because I seriously dislike olives. Family LOVED this and I will be making it again in the future. :) :) :) :)

text:
Made this for company the other night and we cleaned the pan! Followed instructions to the T except made my own enchilada sauce with the "10 minute enchilada sauce" recipe from this site, used whole wheat tortillas, and got 8-9 filled. Stuffed my 13x9 perfectly. Made mine ahead of time but stopped at filling them & placing in pan, let them chill in the fridge. When ready to bake I preheated oven, let them sit at room temp, topped with sauce & cheese just before baking. Served with spanish brown rice. Will definitely make these again!

These are delicious, and got rave reviews from my partner, as well as the play date group I took them to the next day. I used green enchilada sauce. Then I accidentally put all of the ingredients together, oops, so I had to strain the chicken back out to fill the tortillas with. Still delicious!

Prepared the meat a little differently - put the chicken in a crock  pot with a jar of salsa and a package of taco seasoning.  Shredded the meat, and put in the fridge to set overnight. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a delicious recipe! I didn't change much but whenever I need shredded chicken, I cook it in the crockpot. A small amount of chicken broth and a little taco seasoning on low for 4 hours and it shreds super easy. When I made the cream of chicken/sour cream mixture, I added more chili powder and a little salt to flavor. I didn't add the full 1 cup of mixture to the chicken to make sure it wasn't too soupy as other reviewers advised. I also used chicken broth instead of water to simmer the filling for more flavor and added a little garlic to the onion for flavor. The flavor was awesome and I highly recommend!

Display Name:
Kim

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First of all read through numerous reviews and through my own experience with cooking i decided to use chicken breasts (2lb) and I put the chicken (sometimes I even use frozen-solid breasts or thighs) in a crockpot with the taco seasoning, garlic powder, onion powder, chili powder, chopped onion + a 1/4 cup water. Then the chicken is easily shredded (as usual crock pot meats mmmm) and I add 1/2 tsp cumin and two fair sized organic fresh garlic cloves with Med chopped onion and half cup med salsa and hint of extra fresh squeezed lime juice of one lime (other then required in recipe) 4hrs in. Let simmer on low for 6 hours and check to see if not overdone (not dry). filling rest of ingredients to the crock pot and stir it up. Then I just assemble per the directions. Lightly toasted (flour) tortillas before wrapping them and poppng in oven to prevent to soft shells. Topped with shredded cheese and green onions and sour cream.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe. Very TexMex. Some changes and suggestions: I didn't have green chiles, so I substituted a jalapeno (no seeds - sauteed with onions) and about 6 or 7 tablespoons of tomatillo sauce. I also subbed 4-cheese shredded mixture for Cheddar. Really, really nice results. BUT. It was really too rich for our tastes. Next time I will cut the soup and sour cream mixture in half and only use it in the blended meat (not on the bottom of the pan -- use enchilada sauce instead). I'm going to use the blended recipe for tacos or burritos soon. Excellent recipe. Thanks, Angela.

text:
Over all its not a bad tasting recipe. I read a lot of the reviews and try as I may to limit the liquids it still came out like a casserole. I tried both corn and flour tortillas, corn is the way to go. Instead of water I used the  reserved stock from boiling the chicken.  1/2 the sour cream and 1/2 the condensed soup. After chopping and boiling the chicken using your fingers to break up the chicken is faster. I don't think I would make this again too time consuming for what you ge.

text:
I actually haven't made this recipe yet, but I've made very similar.  Ditto Jen - chicken in crock pot practically shreds itself.  I usually dump a small jar of salsa in the pot (love salsa Verde.)  No need for the taco seasoning because the salsa flavor comes through beautifully and you are greatly cutting sodium.  Season to taste after it's cooked. Fresh cilantro would make it so fresh and bold tasting.  I mince a whole bunch of out, stems and all, and stir in at the end of cooking time.

text:
Save yourself the time and shred a rotisserie chicken. My only criticism is that the green onions inside the enchiladas were odd. I would omit these and just sprinkle on top. Maybe if I had simmered the chicken mixture on the stove for the full 20 minutes they'd have been softer, but I felt that timing was wayy too long. Otherwise, great dish! 

Healthy(ish) changes: whole wheat tortillas, low sodium taco seasoning, fat free cream of chicken soup, light sour cream, and reduced fat cheese.

I made this dish a couple nights ago and absolutely loved it! I used corn tortillas instead of flour tortillas for a better flavor and I sprinkled some Cayenne over the enchiladas before putting the cheese on to give it some kick. I would also keep the chicken breasts whole to boil before shredding, as it took FOREVER to shred when it had been cubed. Very yummy and will definitely be making this again!

text:
AWESOME and OUTSTANDING enchiladas.  Followed the recipe with following minor modifications:  diced 2 chipotle peppers in adobe and added to soup/sour cream mix.  At about 1,700 mg these enchiladas are almost a entire days worth of sodium.  I made my own spice mix instead of taco seasoning pack and reduced cheese to 2 cups.  Next time I intend to spray the bottom of pan with cooking spray.  The soup/sour cream mix did not keep the enchiladas from sticking and this will result in further sodium reduction.  This recipe will be enjoyed for a long time.  Thanks for sharing.

country:
None
text:
Wow, what a great recipe!!  Will definitely make again!! I tried to follow it exactly, except my grocery store only had 10" flour tortillas, lite sour cream, and low-sodium cream of chicken condensed soup.  I also added a second can of red enchilada sauce and only used a 3 oz can of sliced olives. This created 6 enchiladas instead of 5 and I had a handful of filling left over (that I ended up not using). It still tasted amazing!! I also had to cook the soup mixture over medium heat at first, as it refused to simmer on low heat. The whole recipe took me 2 hours... definitely not spending that much time again!  I plan to put the onion, half of the scallions, chicken (whole breasts), taco seasoning, onion/garlic powder, and just enough water to cover the chicken in the crockpot for 5+ hours, and then shred it and stir in chilies and lime juice as another reviewer suggested.  All other steps will be the same. I will re-review after I try it that way, but I am pretty confident that it will simplify things a lot!  Thank you for this amazing recipe!

text:
This is really good!  I've made them twice now and my family and roommate love them.  I took the advice of one of the other reviewers and cooked the chicken in the crockpot with the taco spices.  The only other thing I changed was adding more taco seasoning to the chicken.  I usually like mild seasoning, but without the extra seasoning it tasted a bit bland.  I also added 3-4 drops of tabasco sauce. To save prep time, I think next time I'll cook and shred the chicken ahead of time.  The second time I prepared them, I used leftover chicken from the first batch I made, which I had freezed.  It was much faster then to make up the second batch later.

dateLastModified:
2013-01-03T20:10:59.54
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
2991955
Display Name:
RAPTORSHARK
isPro:
False
followersCount:
18
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
81
favoritesCount:
156
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/701635.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First of all my name is Angela so I had to try this haha.  I mostly followed the directions heres what I did: cooked 4 chicken breasts in slow cooker with a can of cream of mushroom and taco seasoning packet ahead of time, which shredded like butter (see my epic mex ckn recipe ;). Then simmered container of sour cream/lo sodium cream mushroom soup/chili powder in small saucepan. In big skillet I sauteed the onions, then added in the chicken along with 2 cans chiles (will use jalapenos next time), cilantro, green onion, lime juice, onion powder/garlic powder/cumin powder, and a cup of the sour cream mixture.  I got 6" corn tortillas bc they were on sale. To soften them, sprayed both sides of each with pam, then microwave like 6 at a time for 40sec with a damp paper towel on top. That way they dont crack when you roll them up.  Filled about 13 of them with the chicken mixture and cheese, then once they were in the pan I topped with enchilada sauce, more shredded cheese, and black olives. Tasted awesome, next time I'm going to leave off the black olives, use jalapenos and cool ranch doritos as the top layer.

Love, love, love this recipe!  Easy to make (though a bit time consuming) and always a crowd pleaser! It's been my go-to for a couple years now and my guests are always impressed. Who doesn't love a casual Mexican dinner? Pair this with some Spanish rice,  beans (I like to prepare both refried & black), and a case of Coronas & you're good to go! To save time, I make the filling the night before then just stuff the tortillas , cover w cheese, etc.. & throw them in the oven & 1/2 hr later - fiesta time!! Enjoy!

text:
Loved the recipe!  It took a lot longer for me to make than I anticipated but it has a great flavor.  I actually made it a little different in order to freeze it.  I mixed all the sauce together and put it inside the enchilla and put the toppings on.  I then wrapped each one individually in foil and then in a zip lock bag for the freezer.  I then can take out as many as I want and either microwave it or bake it for 40 mintutes from frozen or defrost and bake for 25 mintutes.  Turned out great!  I will definetely make this recipe again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband usually says, "Thanks, Honey, that was good." But last night after serving these enchiladads he said, "Those were fantastic! Better than anything I've eaten in a restaurant." Now that is high praise! 

We all thought these were great. I wouldn't say they were easy, though! I made it harder on myself by forgetting to take out some sauce for the vegetarians before I added the chicken, so I basically started all over to make a vegetarian version (using Quorn "chicken" cutlets). 
I used corn tortillas because leftovers with flour tortillas get slimy. As it was, the few leftovers were pretty mushy but still good. I only filled and baked 1/2 of each version rather than have too many leftovers and I'm glad I did. I would rather bake them fresh and use up the filling that way. I used Taco Seasoning I by Bill Echols. I only used half the recipe in each batch. It was just right for me. With it I served Salsa Guacamore by Lauren Heyn. Will definitely make these again! Thank you, Angela!

text:
These were amazing. I cooked the chicken in a slow cooker to save myself some time and steps (cooked w/ the taco seasonings as well as some chicken broth). I used corn tortillas instead of flour, but otherwise followed the recipe to a T. (Actually, because the chicken was so moist after being in the slow cooker, I did not need to add any water to the chicken/onion/soup/seasonings/chilis mixture). These were definitely restaurant quality. I make recipes from this site all the time, and this is only the 2nd or 3rd I've liked enough to take tiem time to rate. Very, very good. Highly recommended.

Did you know you can shred your chicken with a hand mixer? Cook chicken as directed, put in large bowl, and with mixer on low to medium, "stab" chicken repeatedly with beaters until shredded! So easy and time saving!!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This has long been my favourite enchilada recipe, but, it was time to lighten up. I replaced the condensed chicken soup with greek yogurt. To compensate I added 2 tbsp powdered chicken stock to the water step. I reduced the sour cream to less than 1/2 cup. I also added one chopped green pepper and omitted the butter, using PAM spray instead. Salsa was used instead of enchilada sauce and minimum cheese. With these changes the calorie count per enchilada was about 450.

text:
First Enchiladas I ever made, and the best I probably ever had. They are delicious!!! I made these for my mom and dad and I for our American Idol night, and we all practically licked the plate clean. Just perfect, I didn't change a thing, except that I used 7, 8-in Tortillas instead of the bigger ones, and I topped it off with a lil more sour cream and green onions. This will be my go-to Enchilada recipe. Very simple and easy to prepare, not to mention quite cheap.

Very good and very filling.  I shredded 4 leg-thigh pieces I had slow cooked in crockpot. I skipped the butter and chopped onions step and just added more onion powder because of time.  I do not care for canned enchilada sauce so we subbed salsa verde.  This made 8 nice size enchiladas to fill a 9x13 pyrex.  Can't wait to try it with the onions!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
AMAZING enchiladas! I wouldn't necessarily call these "traditional" but once you eat them, you won't really care! I followed the recipe exactly, except rubbed the chicken breasts down with Adobo seasoning and let them sit for about 20 minutes before boiling. Once they were cooked and shredded, I sprinkled a bit more Adobo on.  I also added a bit of extra chili powder and garlic powder to the sauce. I mix a couple of tablespoons of Sofrito into the enchilada sauce as well. I also forgot to add the cheese in the filling, so I put all of it on top. :) Still turned out cheesy and quite flavorful. Will definitely be making again!

text:
These enchiladas were fantastic! I did make some changes to make them healthier and I thought they were still great. I used fat free sour cream, 98% fat free condensed cream of chicken soup, canola oil instead of butter, and a mix of 2% mexican cheese and fat free cheddar cheese. The fat free doesn't melt as good but when mixed with everything I thought it was great!

This was fantastic!! I did as a previous user did and threw the chicken breast (frozen), taco seasoning, onion powder, garlic powder, chili powder, and about a 1 1/4 cups of water in the crockpot and let that sit all day on low. I will definitely be making this again!!

text:
I only used 1.75 lbs of chicken breast,  added 1 tsp of red pepper flakes and 1 tbs of chili powder instead of 1/4 tsp, which still wasn't spicy enough (I tasted a hint of spice).  I used the 98% fat free cream of chicken soup, mexican mixture of shredded cheese, and light sour cream (fat free sour cream is gross).  I had enough filling to make 6 enchiladas (I forced myself to eat 1.5 because I couldn't stop myself but 1 SHOULD have been sufficient).  It's definitely a lot more work but SO worth it.  It's not the healthiest recipe but it's very yummy!

Made this for dinner and it was great. I did change it up some. I dont like chiles or olives so I left them out. I will probably use smaller tortillas so that there were more enchiladas. I used only half a can of the enchiladas sauce as I think it is too spicy. This was a great recipe seeing as I downloaded it in the Albertson's parking lot as my husband was putting in his dinner request.

text:
Too salty for our taste with the taco seasoning and the condensed soup as the recipe is written.  I did try a second time with additional chicken (had a package that was a little of 3 lbs) and it was worth the 5 stars.  Now for our individual preferences, I added little more cumin (1/4 tsp), and fresh chopped cilantro and avocado right before baking.  Thanks for the recipe and this is really a 5 star, easy recipe but just a bit too salty for our preference and I am a salt fanatic.

text:
These warrant the "awesome" in their name. I didn't change the recipe at all and it came out perfect. The only thing that caught off me off guard was the simmering time for the chicken once combined with the onions and chilies; there was not enough liquid to have it simmer for the 20 minutes indicated. So I let the mix heat for about 5 minutes and then started stuffing tortillas. The meat still came out tender and delicious.

text:
Definitely lives up to its name! I added a little bit of cornstarch to the filling because it was a bit thin (I might have measured the sour cream wrong... that stuff gets messy!) and I didn't want it to be a mess when I was trying to fill the tortillas. We also used small-size tortillas and only 1 1/2 cups of cheddar because that's what we had in the house. Both my boyfriend and I loved it and we'll definitely make this again. Bravo Angela!

We LOVED this! Everyone gobbled it up! I threw my chicken in the crockpot with some chicken broth for most of the day, took it out and shredded it. I left out the green onions because I didn't have any, and used green enchilada sauce. YUM!

text:
My husband and I were never fans of Enchilada's before this recipe.  Love using flour instead of corn tortillas.  I have a picky 3 year old so left out the green chiles.  I also only had 6 of the small flour tortillas in so used those and packed them full of chicken.  I baked a couple of frozen chicken breasts in the oven before shredding them.  I added a little salt even though the recipe didnt call for it.  This recipe was so easy to make and so yummy that we all loved it.  This dish will become a regular at our dinner table.

text:
These were not my favorite chicken enchiladas.  The only changes I made were to double the recipe and use corn tortillas.  I thought they had good flavor but I wouldn't use all white meat.  I think they would have been better cooking a whole chicken. I also used green enchilada sauce as I think it is a better flavor combination with chicken enchiladas. Also the sauce I cooked the chicken in didn't cook down so the filling was runny.  I didn't have time to cook it down more.  Probably won't make again.

text:
These were great! My husband actually woke me up to tell me how much he liked them.  I only used 1 lb of chicken breasts and there was plenty of filling for 5 enchiladas - I think it was the perfect goo-to-meat ratio this way and in my opinion 2 lbs would be too much meat. A few other very slight changes: 'original' taco seasoning instead of 'mild' and used closer to 14oz of enchilada sauce [bought the 19oz 'big' can and used about 3/4. Otherwise followed the recipe as written and it was wonderful. My leftovers were mistaken as 'restaurant quality' by several of my co-workers!

text:
I made this after seeing the great reviews. I doubled the recipe and made some for my neighbors. Everyone loved them, even the kids.  My modifications included: adding cilantro, using a mexican cheese blend (didn't measure, did it to my liking) and removing the olives.   I also used another reviewer's suggestion and used a crock pot. Since it was a Sunday, I boiled the chicken, while cooking the other items separately. I then put everything into the crockpot to simmer (except for the sauce that was used in the bottom of the baking dish) and let it simmer for a couple of hours while I did other things. When it was time for dinner, I rolled the enchiladas and baked them for about 20 minutes.

Rating:
5

text:
WOW, incredibly delicious! It tastes better than any I had at Mexican restaurants. I used corn tortillas (like the flavor better) and they did tear after filling them, but when the dish was baked I just cut it into squares and served it that way. I also used shredded chicken that I cooked in a crock pot the day before, the chicken filling was moist and very tender. Will definitely make these again and again.

text:
Great recipe. I followed previous reviewer's advice and boiled the whole breasts instead of cutting them up before hand. Next time I will shred the chicken in the food processor as this did take a couple of minutes by hand and I was too impatient to make the chunks small enough for my liking. Followed the recipe except I omitted the lime juice and used olive oil instead of butter to cook the onions in. Highly recommended, this one is going into rotation in our house and will be proudly served to guests.

I thought these were absolutely phenomenal.  Fantastic flavor and yumminess!  My picky 8-year old devoured them and said they are his favorite.  I definitely don't see them as authentic or anything like that, and mine came out a little soggy and fell apart into a pile of mushy enchilada when I served them, but they tasted SO GOOD that it did not matter!  I probably should have let them cool a little before I served them to prevent that from happening.  The only thing that I changed is that I used corn tortillas instead of flour, because using flour just seemed weird to me.  I'm eating leftovers right now!  Yum, yum, yum!  Thank you!

text:
These are good, just not my favorite chicken enchilada. It is time intensive with a lot of ingredients. If I were to make these again, I would omit all the ingredients in step 2 except the shredded chicken, taco seasoning packet, and water. I would simply simmer these ingredients for 10 minutes before proceeding to step 3. I would also use the "chicken taco seasoning packet" instead of the one suggested.

text:
I omitted the condensed soup to make this recipe gluten free for my daughter.  I also made hers in corn tortillas; however I recommend using wheat tortillas if you can tolerate gluten.  These were excellent; my family devoured them.  Shredding the chicken was not as time consuming as I expected and certainly worth the effort.  I appreciated the black olive & green onion touches on top.  This recipe has made it's way into the regular menu.  Thank you Angela!
